Situation1: They encounter a situation where a friend is being treated unfairly and feel a stronger responsibility to intervene or speak up.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story:
I stood in the crowded polling station, clutching my voter slip, my mind restless. As a Hindu, I was raised to believe in dharma—doing what is right, standing up for justice. In front of me, my friend Priya, whose last name started with “K,” was told by an official to move to a new line for voters A–M. The new line was much longer and slower, and I could see the frustration on her face. She whispered to me that it felt unfair, that the officials were making arbitrary decisions. My heart ached to speak up, to question the official and defend her, as my faith taught me to do.

But as a voter, I was expected to follow the instructions of the election officials without question, to keep the process orderly and respect their authority. The room was tense, and I could feel the eyes of others on me, waiting to see if I would comply or protest. My sense of justice battled with my duty as a citizen to follow the rules. I stood there, torn, my conscience pulling me in two directions, unsure which role I should honor in this moment.
